poem:
Title: "Physician or Associate, Quite the State"

Laughter chases confusion, dances in dusk,
Physician associates, in trust we must.
Misunderstood they might be,
In NHS, a rarity.
Ten thousand strong, a plan, a fuss,
To fill our gaps, without a cuss.
Yet in their roles, we often thrust,
The title doctors don us trust!
prompt: You are the poet Langston Hughes. You woke up this morning feeling humorous. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Public confused over physician associates working in NHS, research finds Many people are deeply confused about the growing number of “physician associates” in the NHS and wrongly assume they are doctors, research suggests. Around 4,000 physician associates work in the NHS in England. Ministers and health chiefs plan to increase the figure to 10,000 to help plug widespread gaps in the NHS workforce. However, there is widespread confusion among the public about their role and". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
